chapter.title: Cross Site Scripting
chapter.para: Cross Site ScriptingXSSCross Site Scripting (XSS) is the scourge of web applications. The vulnerability is a client-side injection attack and occurs when the attacker inserts malicious code into a web page. The malicious code is often sent to the server and later used in a web page provided to subsequent users. This chapter of the book will show you how to use OWASP and ESAPI controls to protect against XSS vulnerabilities.

section.title: Documentation
section.para: Cross Site ScriptingDocumentationXSSDocumentationDocumentation for OWASP Encoder class is located at Class Encoder. Documentation for ESAPI Encoder class is located at Interface Encoder.
OWASP provides two XSS cheat sheets at Cross Site Scripting Prevention Cheat Sheet and DOM based XSS Prevention Cheat Sheet.

section.title: Strategy
section.para: Cross Site ScriptingStrategyXSSStrategyOutput EncodingThe strategy used to defend against XSS is output encoding. Output encoding is context dependent, and different encoder functions will be used depending on how the vulnerable parameter is used. The vulnerable parameter can be present in HTML, URLs, JavaScript, CSS or JSON.
Output encoding translates dangerous characters into a benign representation for display on a web page. The table below shows safe ways to encode dangerous characters.

section.title: Canonicalization
section.para: CanonicalizationSometimes you will need to use an ESAPI control on a value, but the value may already be encoded. To avoid double encoding you can call canonicalize to normalize a value before input validation and encoding. Input validation is covered in .

example.title: Canonicalization, ESAPI Encoder
example.programlisting:
<!-- Receive parameter in request from submit -->
String UNTRUSTED = request.getParameter("SomeParameter");
UNTRUSTED = ESAPI.encoder().canonicalize(UNTRUSTED);
...

<!-- Always validate after canonicalization -->
String validated = validateParameterValue(UNTRUSTED);
...

<!-- Prepare value for repsonse in web page -->
String encoded = ESAPI.encoder().encodeForHTML(validated);

section.para: If you have to call canonicalize multiple times, then it could be an attacker supplying data already encoded to evade detection. If you find you need to call canonicalize, then consider returning an error. Don't allow an attacker to have multiple attempts on your code.

section.title: HTML Body
section.para: Cross Site ScriptingHTML BodyXSSHTML BodyThe primary defense against XSS in HTML body is HTML escaping or Entity encoding. Use the encoding method when the attacker controlled text is displayed to the user in a <body> tag.

section.title: HTML Attribute
section.para: Cross Site ScriptingHTML AttributeXSSHTML AttributeThe primary defense against XSS in HTML attribute is HTML escaping or Entity encoding. Use the encoding method when the attacker controlled text is part of an attribute, like in an <input> or <image> tag.

section.title: HTML Body vs Attribute
section.para: The main difference between encodeForHTML and encodeForHTMLAttribute is, encodeForHTML does not encode the space character, while encodeForHTMLAttribute encodes the space character as &#x20.

section.title: HTML Hyperlink Tag
section.para: Cross Site ScriptingHyperlinkXSSHyperlinkA HTML hyperlink tag requires two different encodings. One encoding is for the URL or URI component, and the second is for the HTML attribute. Note that the sample code always uses forURIComponent. forURIComponent is safe in all relevant contexts, unlike forURI.

example.title: HTML Hyperlink Tag, OWASP Encoder
example.programlisting: String url = "/orders/" + Encode.forURIComponent(UNTRUSTED) + "&order=1"; Click Me

section.para: If the untrusted data is a fragment of a URL, then use the component encoder as shown below.

example.title: HTML Hyperlink Tag, URL Fragment, OWASP Encoder
example.programlisting: String url = "/search?value=" + Encode.forURIComponent(UNTRUSTED) + "&order=1"; Click Me

section.title: JavaScript
section.para: Cross Site ScriptingJavaScriptXSSJavaScriptThe primary defense against XSS in JavaScript is avoid doing so. Allowing attacker controlled data directly inside a script is dangerous.

You should avoid code similar to the following example because it is nearly impossible to guard against XSS. DOM-based XSS is nearly impossible to prevent because the controls run client-side, not server-side. Most controls can be bypassed onerror.
Encoding can be used when the attacker controlled text is part of JavaScript. This remediation includes all DOM-based JavaScript event handler attributes such as onfocus, onclick, and onload.

section.title: innerHTML
section.para: Cross Site ScriptinginnerHTMLXSSinnerHTMLThe primary defense against XSS in dangerous sinks like innerHTML is to avoid it and use a safe sink like textContent or innerText. If you must use innerHTML, then the defense is HTML escaping or Entity encoding. Use the encoding method when the attacker controlled text is displayed to the user in the innerHTML.

section.title: Cascading Style Sheets
section.para: Cross Site ScriptingCSSXSSCSSThe primary defense against XSS in Cascading Style Sheets is hexadecimal encoding. Use the encoding method for style blocks and attributes in HTML.
Hexadecimal encoding is applied to U+0000-U+001f, ", ', \, <, &, (, ), /, >, U+007f, line separator (U+2028), paragraph separator (U+2029).
